text: Everyone, like Richard, keeps bringing up the point that the UK is damned without the UE... Has that ever been a proper and healthy relationship for any two parties to have? How can we not call that "complete dependence" upon the EU? Being economically united is fine and a prosperous thing even, but I can't reconcile how the anti-brexiters think the ability to be independent, to have a country that can support itself, can be a bad thing. Women who are in abusive relationships are told the same thing; that no other man will love them or take care of them the way they do. Surely no person would tell that woman to give into that fear! Of course, it'd probably be more difficult and scary for her to abandon her abuser, but her independence and autonomy is worth the risk. When you're not independent, you're completely incapable of calling yourself "autonomous."

EU standards are the best in the world, for product safety, limitation or abolishment of contaminates, environmental standards, along with workers rights, health care, etc. Remember it was these standards that disallowed lead-contaminated Chinese toys from entering the EU. In any case the USA fought vigorously to reduce EU standards calling them an "economic tsunami" for the US economy, one that is legendary for its lack of regulation and protections. 

Economically, the EU had very little to do with globalization which was one of the worst ideas of modern economic practice.

The EU also sets political freedom/human rights standards which has prevented Turkey from entering the EU, although they very much want to. Turkish treatment of the Kurds is certainly at the top of that list. The EU have warned Poland of the danger of dismantling the rule of law, which won't be tolerated. 

The hardest hit in England will be workers, as England will lean towards an American style economy free from troublesome regulations that impede massive profits and allow for environmental irresponsibility.

text:
@nathan osgood I'm upset of the following turn of events too. Do you see me swearing?

UK does have its own points based immigration system, and those rules apply to me as a commonwealth citizen. These rules are more onerous than the aussie style; so when applied to EU citizens, we will see a huge drop in numbers due to the min salary requirement for work visa approval. With regards to high numbers from non-EU, that's not a problem at all. If you analyse the numbers that came in as at end of March 2016 from the ONS website, 170k are on student visas, the largest portion of non-EU immigration. Overseas students are good because they pay the full tuition fees of about Â£18k pa; so for a typical 3 year course + expenses, each would bring in about Â£80k. Total Â£13bn into UK economy. About 90k came in on a work visa and this is now capped due to uncontrolled flow from EU. The main difference between non-EU and EU migrants is that non-EU migrants cannot claim welfare benefits and once their visas have expired, they have to leave the country. To get indefinite leave to remain, there will be another set of rules. Back to main issue, mass migration from EU needs to stop.ï»¿
The UK immigration system is very discriminatory and not many remainers realise this or even care to be honest. So it's laughable when they accuse those who voted leave as racist or xenophobic without knowing how non EU migrants are treated. If anything I would say a remain vote is an endorsement for discrimination. The min salary requirement varies depending on jobs, the gov approved list of shortage jobs will state how much for each occupation. 

Most of the immigration from the commonwealth are students paying twice the amount of tuition fees that Europeans pay but don't have to pay because the British government loans them since they're Europeans, are kicked out after their education. The statistics are laughable for the non eu. Most of them don't stay. Also the new rules made in April that doesn't let common wealth students extend their visa for an optional placement, masters and the 35000 annual salary all give eu students and workers an edge in the competition which is unfair considering they can clean toilets and stay back and the UK is losing potential engineers and doctorsï»¿. All of the point system and the regulations are compromised for eu citizens most of whom don't move for high skill contribution and now eu citizens have an unfair edge since they could do the optional placement between years in their bachelors and integrated courses which were previously promised to commonwealth citizens too. 12500 and 19500, pounds and etc are huge money man compared to 9000 pounds a year. And most of them are hard earned and loaned money from their home countries that people have committed to come and study and work here unlike freebie Europeans most of whom don't even like the English culture. Personal experiences mate ï»¿

The Â£35k salary is the requirement for indefinite leave to remain application after 5 years of staying in UK legally. Many find this criteria hard to fulfil. The minimum salary for a work visa stands somewhere at 24000 pounds mate. Europeans can earn like 11000 pounds a year non taxable self employed salary and apply for settlement. I have done my fair share of research unlike most young remainers who feel broken because they can't go tour Europe without a visa. most of the people benefiting from the eu are not even regular people but businesses and Westminsterï»¿.  not many people can earn over 20000 pounds for a work visa or 35000 pounds for a settlement. this is racism and discrimination

Any system is better than no system which is what the EU citizens are enjoying at the moment, freedom to live/work with no restrictions. The argument that an immigration system imposed on EU citizens will not have any impact is nonsense, i hope they come up with a system which will be fair and treat all immigrants equally.ï»¿

text:
If I may, I have a theory as to why Boris has refused to run for party leader/PM. Thought I'd mention it since you mentioned him in passing.

If you look at his writings from back in the day when he was merely a journalist, you'd notice that not one of his works contains any hint even of euro-scepticism, let alone of any desire for this new 'independence'. If you look at how his 'outside of the EU' hopes for Britain are essentially to remain in the free market, to do nothing to immigration, blah blah blah. The only conclusion one could possibly come to is that he's not as behind the Brexit vote as he would want the public to think.

So why join it, you may ask? Well, Boris studied Classics at Oxford (at my college, Balliol, actually). So it's safe to say he's very familiar with how Augustus, first emperor of Rome, changed the state from a steadfast Republic into a pseudo-Monarchy, seemingly without anyone noticing. How did Augustus do it? To put it simply, he presented himself as the rebel against a status quo which, in the eyes of many, was a failing system (sound familiar?). He placed himself as the voice of reason, or so the sources written after his reign record, among a rabble of infighting and protracted bureaucracy (sound familiar?). He presented himself as the reluctant leader, forced into service for his country not out of ambition, but out of duty (sound familiar?). Think of Cinncinatus, the dictator of Rome in 390 BC who took on the dictatorship for three days, solved the crisis, and gave up power, returning to his humble farm - the reluctant but dutiful leader.

I believe that boris is attempting something similar. He's the voice of reason against Farage and Gove's trigger happiness, he's the voice of reason against the EU which 52% of the population apparently doesn't want (that's another discussion for another time). And yet he didn't step up as an ambitious politician when Cameron fell: he's the reluctant leader.

So, what next? Well, whoever inherits Cameron's position to tide us over until the next General Election will, or certainly greatly risks, inheriting a climate of economic depression, and certainly will inherit the monumental task of successfully triggering Article 50 and negotiations. The most likely outcome is that the 'caretaker Prime Minister' will be seen as a failure, and will resign as leader when a new election comes around. Much like Gordon Brown, though he rather mucked things up for himself.

Boris doesn't want that. After all, he's the supreme careerist, joining the side of the most important UK decision in over a decade he disagrees with just to get the headlines and exposure he wants. No, Boris will, throughout the period in office of Theresa May, or Michael Gove, or whoever it ends up being, will be the anti-PM. He will once again be the voice of reason, but this time against a PM who in most minds will be a failure, rather than Farage.

Then, when the next leader of the Tories resigns or whatever, he will be ripe for the takeover before a new General Election. When all the worry of being perceived as a failure following the referendum will be gone, he will be able to be the successful successor to the failed caretaker.

But those are just my two cents.

text:
If you think the EU is undemocratic you just don't understand how it works. It's just a democracy of a larger amount of people than the UK, just as everyone in the UK is ruled by a government which cannot represent everyone's will perfectly so the EU can't represent all of the populations will perfectly.

Farage was a member of the fisheries committee of the European parliament, he complains about EU fisheries policy yet he attended just one of the 42 meetings while he has been a member. Farage had some power which could have used to push his complaints but he didn't.

He is a dishonest man who overstates how much we give to the EU (far less than Â£350 million a week) over exaggerates how much of the laws that apply to us are made there (and even if there were more it is still democratic). Lies about the impact of immigrants on the economy, EU immigrants pay more in tax than they take in benefits, they do not increase unemployment or reduce wages of people already living in the country (if you don't believe me on any of these just do a quick search in google scholar, there are many studies). 

He has whipped up a storm of misplaced xenophobic anger. The problems people face today have been incorrectly blames on immigrants and it is unfair and frankly nasty.

Brexit will ruin London as a financial centre, without passporting into Europe London will no longer have quite the attraction to financial companies that it does now. People may say who cares but it is a significant part of the economy that employs a lot of people. Banks aren't all bad without loans how would people buy houses or expand their businesses?

Farage has lied and mislead people and should not be praised.

I've noticed that all your 'sources' point to The Independent.  Your not the only one who does it.  All the others who try to shed Farage in a negative light seem to always point to that website.
I'm not going to call you an idiot or a fool but quite frankly, your accusation that Farage is a fascist, is ludicrous and it has no basis.  If you want to know what a fascist in UK politics looks like, look at Nick Griffin and the BNP.
Farage is actually putting the interests of Britain first.  The point is people can't see it or don't want to see it because they know he is right in so many things.  He's not afraid to take crap from opposition and in all his years at the European Parliament he's taken boos, hisses and people trying to shout over him.  Over the last couple of years, it's actually changed.  He's been getting cheers, rounds of applause and people standing.  Why don't you actually look at some of his speeches on here instead of shoving clickbait at people.

text:
@The Tick It is exasperating to hear the praise for Farage. It's precisely the arguments for Brexit that are spurious, and the burden of proof for leaving EU lies with that side of the argument. If you want to present arguments for leaving EU, go ahead. But everything I have heard has sounded like nostalgia for a past that never was: the popular "Make America/Britain Great Again" argument. I really don't know if Farage is a liar and a fraud or if he is only suffering from delusions of grandeur. It is analogous to the way founders of cults make up stuff, but then end up believing in it themselves.
It's as if Alan Partridge had popped up as a politician and millions of people are praising him for "telling it like it is", or "saying what he really thinks". I find him ignorant and rude, and frankly he makes me feel embarrassed to be British. 
I don't have time to address all the arguments of Brexit (I actually have a "real job" to do!). But please read the following article if you seriously want to think about this problem (Sorry, I don't mean to sound condescending, but hey, I am much older than you!).
http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/mind-guest-blog/brexit-and-trump-when-fear-triumphs-over-evidence/
author: Yellow Hills

text:
That Scientific American blog is appallingly bad and is basically the same as your argument of "We are the clever ones you have to do as we say!" "You're too stupid and fearful to make rational logical decisions like we superior beings!".

I am so glad the British people told all the experts to get stuffed. Politicians can always find an expert somewhere that tells them what they want to hear, that's why we don't believe them.

Now if the remainers had made any actual arguments during the campaign and not just told us all to do as we are told or WW3 would be around the corner I might have listened to them.

But if you want some arguments for leaving the EU here are my primary ones:

Democracy: Yes, we elect the European Parliament so there is one (of 5) presidents elected by the people, and those MEP's choose the Commission president. But there's no getting around it, this is a step backwards from electing MP's from whom is chosen the executive. It's the first step backwards for people power since the Magna Carta as far as I can tell. There is zero reform of this proposed at all, and even if proposed I see zero chance of it happening. This single point alone is reason to leave.

Habeas Corpus: Our ancient right of Habeas Corpus has been overturned by the European Arrest Warrant. Already British citizens have been removed from their homes, sent to foreign jails and spent months if not years before being put before a judge to see if their is enough evidence to hold them. We cannot allow our protections against tyrannical governments to be eroded.

These are far more fundamental than having the luxury of doing a bit of work in Spain without filling out any forms, or French wine being 5% cheaper.

text:
The EU is probably more democratic than your british political with it's house of lords (really why still have a house just for nobility from medieval times?) The EU parliamant can make laws and of course it has to be incorporated in UK's law, how else will it work. Aren't laws made by your government incorporated in the law which needs to be followed by cities and regions? I am not going to speak about Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal, ... because I don't have so much knowledge about it and feel it might have been handled the wrong way. Germany's immigrant problem isn't directly caused by the EU, because Merkel 'invited' them to Germany. Even without the EU she might have made the same mistake.

But now, what do you hope to achieve by leaving? No more EU rules? Surprise, you'll still have to follow them if you want to trade with the EU, look at finland and switzerland, it even gets worse, you don't have a voice anymore when rules are made or changed . No more money to EU? Again look at finland and switzerland, they pay the EU for the privilege to trade. No more free movement of persons? Again it will still be in a trade agreement if the EU makes the same agreement as with other non EU european nations. 

So what do you actually gain?

Is the EU perfect? No. Does it have to change? yes. Can it? yes, if not now than when this 'brainwashed' young people really get in. These young people have an image of the EU in their head that's good. We know things need to change, and we will. EU is the future, no european nation on it's own has much power in the world politically and economically. The problem now is that there has been too much expansion in too little time. It might take a while to resolve the problems caused by this, but we will. And if not we'll just have to make it smaller, back to the basics, meaning western/south european countries and germany. Even if the EU falls apart, you can be damn certain something similar takes it place, but it will have learned from earlier mistakes, start small and expand slowly only when countries meet really heavy demands, like similar welfare systems, etc.

text:
@qetoun
Indeed, and that is the greatest problem. All the power is with the 28 heads of state. Ofcourse the EU can't function if they are in charge, they don't wish to do what's good for the entire EU, but only for what is good for themselves/their countries. The eastern countries are a perfect example. If money is being distributed, they are first in line, when refugees needs to be located they oppose it harsly. The EU parliament needs more power about certain subjects. For example the environment, energy, ... these things can better be organised on EU level than national level. This is where they should start. Together with better refugee policy, outer border security and inner security (like EU FBI/intelligence). This are things they should focus on most now and where the EP should have much more powers.

Something I believe personally a lot in, but shouldn't be on EU level is a shared military of western european countries (Belgium, Netherlands, UK, france, Germany, perhaps Italy and spain too.) Reports state that this could reduce costs treefold while still keeping the same strength. Of course nationalist will be highly opposed to this idea, but I believe this is the future. What are the reason not to? independence? No one wants a new war between (western) european states, so the military should never be used for independence reasons. Risk of one country taking power? Rules need to be put into place obviously to stop something from happening. Leadership? Still ranks, even now with joined operation rank superceeds nationality (or so it should be). Language? English, most spoken language looked at all fields (internet, air, science, worldwide exposure, ...).

I know this might be really farfetched future talk. But Its is the future in my eyes.

@garply101 I know that, the fact is that with this kind ofÂ populist dialogue of Farage a very extreme situation is depicted that doesn't correspond with reality. When you go in deeper dialogue with people actually voting Leave for this reason, you'll notice they don't know jack shit about immigration in the UK nor of the huge benefits they entail for UK economy.

Furthermore, certain sectors within UK are massively benefitting from the EU immigration because of a mismatch between labour market and labour supply. 11% of all staff and overÂ aÂ quarter of doctors within the UK are non-British.
author: Kevin H

text: +Kevin H There's both positive and negative immigration. Britain can now choose which immigration they can have... including doctors and nurses who are welcome. instead of open mass immigration that becomes a drain and creates issues within communities.
author: garply101

text:
The negative effects of immigration are so marginal compared to the positive that it doesn't even remotely make a case for a Brexit. Just to put it into perspective, in Belgium we have an immigration rate of almost double the rate of the UK. The real problem is the xenophobic atmosphere that is created. When you look into public surveys in the UK you indeed see that migration is PERCEIVED as one of the biggest threats, yet this is not reflected in objective data. And that is the main issue.

I have yet to see an interview where Farage actually comes with hard and sound data or figures to build his case.

In addition, it is a very self-centered approach to politics which is one of the many reasons EU will be reluctant to grant a tariff-free access to the single market.
Free movement of goods AND citizens are the backbone of EU philosophy, one will not be granted without the other.

You any idea how much money is wasted on the NHS? Not bothering to employ correct numbers of staff and yet paying 3 or 4 times the going rate for agency staff to fill in, not just now and then, but on a daily basis,  multiply this over several hospitals per major city, not to mention all the time wasted through pen pushing etc. Not long ago I had my father in law transfered from one hospital to another in the early hours, and all I could see were about 7 nurses on this ward all filling in documents one after another, red tape and bureaucracy gone mad. I do know that if we ever manage reducing the numbers down on immigration it could help. My wife has been ill for atleast 2 years, and needs regular appointments to see her Doctor, in that time, no matter how many times she tries, has only managed to see her face to face about 3 times, all other appointments are just call back telephone consultations, which never really help. Whenever we do get appointments, I have witnessed without exaggeration, a full waiting room each time with maybe 25 Asian or black against 3 or 4 white. The staff are Asian too so they can communicate properly.
author: Gray Edgar

text:
Hmmm,  St George Was a Palestinian. But there you go. 
I don't think it's fair to call Farage a full on racist though. That's merely how the left wing dominated media has portrayed him. (doesn't mean I trust him, but the loony left does need to be counterbalanced) He is in favour of a points based immigration system which is identical to that being used very successfully elsewhere in the world. It's already almost impossible to emigrate from Britain to anywhere outside Europe, the USA notably. And getting a job anywhere in Europe is almost impossible despite the "rules" of the EU. We're one of the only countries in the EU that actually worked within those rules anyway. Unless you were transfered within a company. 
The main message that Farage has tried to get across though, must be heard. The EU is a federal political union. A wholly unelected government. That's not what people signed up for. And we definitely did not sign up to having all our production industries shut down and moved to mainland Europe because the money we paid in was being used to subsidise our competition on eastern Europe. We didn't sign up to having to work some of the longest hours, for the lowest pay in the world while the French, German and Italians enjoyed the exact opposite. We didn't sign up to pay for the unification of Germany. We already paid for it to be rebuilt once. Something most younger people are ignorant of; British people were still living with food and fuel rationing until 1954 because we were pumping money into the rebuilding of  (West) Germany. Our taxes built Germany's entire infrastructure not once, not twice, but three times in one century. And still Merkel sticks her greedy paw out and demamds more. Not raiding our coffers she's now turning on the Greeks. Screwing them over. Though I've no sympathy for a nation where the vast majority of the populace hasn't paid any income tax for the last fifty years. Am I "right wing"?? No I'm mist certainly not, I've fought against right wing regimes. And left. I actually think party politics is an outmoded and failed concept. I just don't choose to be ignorant to the facts of history. And I find the continuing merry-go-round of repeating history's mistakes bizarre, asinine, stupidity. The rich are getting richer, the poor, poorer. The British prime minister that opened that gap up the furthest of any? Tony Blair.  A labour prime minister. SMH some people really need to wake up and smell the coffee.

text:
BREXIT AND THE BEGINNING OF THE END OF GLOBALISM AND MULTICULTURAL "EXPERIMENT" IN EUROPE
EU was initially created to end hostile relations between European countries. However, gradually it became a promoter of destructive ideologies like multiculturalism, globalism and feminism. It also supported immigration from Muslim majority countries which now has become a menace in many European countries. Culturally, Britain is closer to USA than other European countries. So Euroscepticism in the British context is justified. I want to see all Anglophone countries to become one United States of Anglo-Saxons (USA, Britain, Canada minus Quebec, Australia, New Zealand and Ireland). BREXIT is more than just economics. It is also about anti-immigration sentiments. England is "ravaged" by immigration and most Britons live in England. Except London (which is only notionally English due to immigration), everywhere else in England, BREXIT supporters won. Wales too supported the BREXIT campaign. Northern Ireland and Scotland want to stay back in EU. Britain is now more divided than before. It should rename itself as "DK" (Divided Kingdom of Britain). The obsolete monarchy is opposed by most people in Britain. Nothing holds Britain together any more. Multiculturalism, immigration, globalist politics and feminism should be globally opposed. Monoculturalism should be promoted. The United Nations (UN) should also disappear, because it has failed to achieve its objectives. "we pay 55 million pounds a day as a contribution. some of that, David, is the rebate which doesn't go. But our gross contribution is 55 million a day."

Your children's future and right to rule themselves being secured is far more important than some numbers on a screen. My predecessors died in their droves to secure my right to govern my country, and for my country to exist. I am more than willing to sacrifice everything I own to do the same for my children.

Any Americans want to answer this... How much would you have given on the 4th July if you was alive back then? To secure your independence?
